key_points: Leslie Grossman, an actor from "American Horror Story," states she mostly used rubber or air guns for shooting scenes.
The fatal shooting on the set of "Rust" by Alec Baldwin, resulting in cinematographer Halyna Hutchins' death, has reignited debate on real firearms on sets.
"The Rookie" and "The Boys" among shows that banned real firearms following the "Rust" incident.
A petition to ban real guns from film and TV sets has garnered nearly 70,000 signatures.
California state senator and New Mexico Governor advocate for legislation banning real firearms and live ammo on sets.
Film industry's safety questioned by filmmaker Bandar Albuliwi and Parkland shooting survivor Cameron Kasky.
Advances in visual effects technology make the use of real firearms unnecessary for authenticity in production.
Visual effects artists can easily create gun effects like muzzle flashes in post-production.
Concerns raised about on-set safety standards and oversight, particularly outside Los Angeles.
Leslie Grossman highlights a culture that often silences safety concerns, stressing no story is worth risking lives.
spokespersons: Michelle Lujan Grisham (Governor of New Mexico)
Bandar Albuliwi (Filmmaker and Author of the Change.org petition)
